Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 2, 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Application No. 393 of 1967. Appellant appeared in person. C. Bhandare, S. B. Wad and, B. D. Sharma, for the respondent.

This is an appeal by special leave from a judg- ment of the Bombay High Court finding the appellant who is an Advocate, guilty of contempt of court and sentencing him to simple imprisonment for a term of four weeks and a fine of Rs. 1,000/-. It was directed that in default of payment of the fine he would have to undergo simple imprisonment for a further period of four weeks.

to take action for contempt of court under s. 3  2  of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952, hereinafter called the Act. issues.text: Whether the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 is unconstitutional and invalid as it violates Articles 20 and 21 of the Constitution, provides no procedure, and the High Court failed to follow normal procedure or improperly delegated to the District Judge?

anchor.surface_text: The Act is unconstitutional and invalid. It violates Articles 20 and 21 of the Constitution. No procedure has been provided in the Act and therefore if is bad. Even the normal procedure which should be followed in such cases has not been followed. The High Court was not entitled to call for a report from the District Judge or to delegate its functions ,including the examination of witnesses to the District Judge.

issues.text: Whether the District Judge could give findings or consider reports of judges not shown to appellant, depriving opportunity to cross-examine?

anchor.surface_text: The appellant raised two preliminary objections before the High Court. The first was that the District Judge could only submit a record of evidence and could not give his findings and, secondly, he could not take into consideration the reports of the two judges which had not been shown to the appellant. Another objection raised was that the reports of the Judicial Officers could not have been relied upon because the appellant had no opportunity to cross-examine them.

issues.text: Whether the show cause notice confined to paragraph 1 of the transfer application meant statements therein could not constitute contempt?

anchor.surface_text: The show cause notice issued by the High Court containing the charge of contempt was confined only to paragraph 1 of the transfer application. The statements made in that paragraph could not by themselves constitute contempt.

issues.text: The question which immediately arises is whether an allegation of the nature made in para 1 in the circumstances of the present case in a transfer application would amount to contempt of the two judges Sarvshri Sayyid and Baadkar?

anchor.surface_text: The question which immediately arises is whether an allegation of the nature made in para 1 in the circumstances of the present case in a transfer application would amount to contempt of the two judges Sarvshri Sayyid and Baadkar. The High Court made a detailed examination of the evidence adduced before the District Judge and also relied on the reports of Sarvshri Sayyid and Baadkar.

issues.text: Whether mere statement that a Magistrate is friendly with a party who is an advocate and enjoys his hospitality constitutes contempt under s. 3 unless imputing improper motives?

arguments.claim: The Contempt of Courts Act, 1952 is unconstitutional and invalid as it violates Articles 20 and 21 of the Constitution, provides no procedure, and the High Court improperly called for report from and delegated functions to the District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The Act is unconstitutional and invalid. It violates Articles 20 and 21 of the Constitution. No procedure has been provided in the Act and therefore if is bad. Even the normal procedure which should be followed in such cases has not been followed. The High Court was not entitled to call for a report from the District Judge or to delegate its functions ,including the examination of witnesses to the District Judge.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed that para 1 allegations do not constitute contempt under s.3 as mere friendship without imputation of improper motives does not scandalize the court.

arguments.claim: Appellant's conduct in transfer application attacks integrity and honesty of courts of Judicial Magistrate and Civil Judge, scandalizes and maligns them; action for contempt under s.3 of Contempt of Courts Act required.

anchor.surface_text: While dismissing the transfer application of the appellant in the criminal complaint filed by Jagiasi in the, court of Shri P. D. Sayyid the Additional Sessions Judge recorded an order that a report be submitted to the High Court for considering the conduct of the appellant and the course adopted by him in making the transfer application and in making imputations or aspersions against the Judicial Officers and to take action for contempt of court under s. 3  2  of the Contempt of Courts Act, 1952, hereinafter called the Act. This was done after reproducing three paragraphs from the transfer application and expressing an opinion that the appellant had attempted to attack the integrity and honesty of the courts of the Judicial Magistrate and the Civil Judge and to scandalize and to malign the same.

arguments.court_reasoning: Allegations in para 1 do not constitute contempt; High Court confined notice to para 1 which lacks imputation of improper motives.

arguments.claim: Allegations in para 1 not proved after examination of evidence; however serious in nature, appellant pitched case higher to prove bribery, no apology tendered, and as advocate makes contempt more serious.

anchor.surface_text: It came to the conclusion that the allegations made by the appellant had not been proved. It was observed that these allegations in the above quoted paragraph which means paragraph 1 were quite serious. The High Court was also influenced by the fact that the appellant had pitched the case higher and tried to prove that the two judges concerned were continuously receiving from Mr. Jagiasi presents of large value in the shape of sarees and other articles and thus receiving bribes so as to indiscreetly favour Mr. Jagiasi and the litigants whom he represented in their Court.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court confined to para 1; mere friendship allegation without improper motive imputation does not amount to scandalizing court even if not proved.

arguments.claim: Allegations in para 1 of transfer application do not constitute contempt as mere statement of Magistrate's friendship and hospitality from advocate does not impute improper motives or scandalize the court unless tendency to create distrust in public mind.

Test for contempt by scandalizing court is whether impugned statement interferes with due course of justice or proper administration of law, or creates apprehension about judge's integrity; mere personal defamation insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has, after a review of all the relevant decisions, laid down in Perspective Publications (P) Ltd. Anr. v. State of Maharashtra 1 , inter alia, the following principles - It will not be right to say that the commitments for contempt for scandalizing the, court have become obsolete. The summary jurisdiction by way of contempt must be exercised with great care caution and only when its exercise is necessary for the proper administration of law and justice.

arguments.claim: Allegations in transfer applications can constitute contempt under s.3 if scandalizing like in Revashankar case (conspiracy, bribe imputations), but distinguished here as no such serious aspersions.

Some latitude allowed in transfer applications for allegations of bias apprehension, but cannot exceed to scurrilous scandalizing; mere intimacy claim without intent to insult not contempt as in Emperor v. Murli Dhar.
Summary jurisdiction for contempt exercised only for grave scurrilous attacks lowering court prestige; not for mere allegations in transfer apps without exceeding limits as in Swarnamayi Panigrahi.

holdings.text: It is wholly unnecessary to decide points 1 to 4 because the appellant must succeed on the 5th point.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion it is wholly unnecessary to decide points 1 to 4 because the appellant must succeed on the 5th point. This Court has, after a review of all the relevant decisions, laid down in Perspective Publications

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disposition on narrower ground of para 1 not constituting contempt makes other points moot.

holdings.text: The summary jurisdiction by way of contempt must be exercised with great care caution and only when its exercise is necessary for the proper administration of law and justice.

anchor.surface_text: The summary jurisdiction by way of contempt must be exercised with great care caution and only when its exercise is necessary for the proper administration of law and justice. It is open to any one to express fair, reasonable and legitimate criticism of any act or conduct of a judge in his judicial capacity or even to make a proper and fair comment on any decision given by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of principles from Perspective Publications case.

holdings.text: A distinction must be made between a mere libel or defamation of a judge and what amounts to a contempt of the court. The test in each case would be whether the impugned publication is a mere defamatory attack on the judge or whether it is calculated to interfere with the due course of justice or the proper administration of law by his court.

anchor.surface_text: A distinction must be made between a mere libel or defamation of a judge and what amounts to a contempt of the court. The test in each case would be whether the impugned publication is a mere defamatory attack on the judge or whether it is calculated to interfere with the due course of justice or the proper administration of law by his, court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts test from Perspective Publications to distinguish personal defamation from interference with justice.

holdings.text: Allegations made even in a transfer application casting aspersions on a judicial officer can constitute contempt of his court within s. 3 of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows State of Madhya Pradesh v. Revashankar where serious aspersions like conspiracy and bribe constituted contempt.

holdings.text: The mere statement that a Magistrate is friendly with a party who happens to be an advocate and enjoys his hospitality or has friendly relations with him will constitute contempt unless there is an imputation of some improper motives as would amount to scandalizing the court itself and as would have a tendency to create distrust in the popular mind and impair the confidence of the people in the courts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Allegations in para 1 lack imputation of improper motives; applies scandalizing test distinguishing from Revashankar.

holdings.text: The allegations contained in para 1 of the transfer application may or may not amount to defamation of the two judges but to constitute contempt the other tests which have been discussed above must be fulfilled.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court notice and proceedings confined to para 1, which fails contempt tests; distinguishes defamation from contempt.

holdings.text: Though some latitude has to be given in a transfer application... a person cannot be allowed to commit contempt of court by making allegations of a serious and scurrilous nature scandalizing the court and imputing improper motives to the judge trying the case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances latitude for bias claims in transfer apps with prohibition on scandalizing; follows Emperor v. Murli Dhar and distinguishes Swarnamayi.

holdings.text: The notice on the face of it discloses no such allegation which could be regarded as falling within the rule laid down by this Court and by a series of decisions of the Privy Council in which this head of contempt i.e. scandalizing court has come up for examination.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Show cause notice based on para 1 lacks elements of scandalizing contempt per established precedents.

anchor.surface_text: A distinction must be made between a mere libel or defamation of a judge and what amounts to a contempt of the court. The test in each case would be whether the impugned publication is a mere defamatory attack on the judge or whether it is calculated to interfere with the due course of justice or the proper administration of law by his, court.
